Biosciences
Rationale
We are unexpectedly losing the expertise to teach the two obesity lectures on LIFE309 from 2016/17 onwards. The topic requires specialist research insight that we cannot easily replace, and it has been agreed that the most pragmatic solution is to lose these two lectures. This is less than 10% change in the module content, and will have no impact on the learning and teaching, or assessment, strategies.
Blurb
Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
"​
​Communication skills
"
How this is developed:
"Self-directed learning, tutorials"

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
"​
​Problem solving skills
"
How this is developed:
"Self-directed learning, tutorials, lectures"

Skill/Other Attribute 3:
"​
​Lifelong learning skills
"
How this is developed:
"Self-directed learning"
Educational Aims
To introduce current techniques and models used to study molecular and cellular physiology;

To review the latest research developments in molecular and cellular physiology and in human diseases, including cancer, obesity, and cystic fibrosis;

To develop in students deep understanding of cellular regulatory physiology mechanisms in order to enhance their ability to discuss the relevant research literature. 
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will build upon Level 5 systems physiology and introduce the techniques and concepts of molecular and cellular physiology. The students will understand the nature of leading research initiatives as they are applied in investigations into physiological processes and human disease. The module will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials, and will be assessed by continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus explores fundamental principles of cellular and molecular physiology, key techniques, and their application in research into human disease.

Topic 1

The central dogma of molecular biology: multi-level regulation of gene/protein expression by transcription factors, chromatin, non-coding RNAs and protein turnover;

Methods to engineer and measure gene expression in cells, tissues and organisms.


Topic 2

Protein biology: structure, function and systems analysis;

Protein folding: mechanisms, prediction and disorders;

Exploring the proteome using quantitative mass spectrometry and interaction mapping, applications in cell biology and human disease.


Topic 3

Imaging physiological processes: from cells to organisms;

Visualising and measuring protein distribution, interactions and dynamics in live cells;

High resolution in vivo imaging in physiology research.


Topic 4

Model organisms in physiology research: from yeast to mice;

The pros and cons of yeast, flies, worms and mice;

Using model organisms to study protein function and interaction networks, stem cells, neurobiology and physiological processes.


Topic 5

Research into human diseases;

Cystic fibrosis: abnormal airway smooth muscle function and the search for improved therapies;

Cancer biology and targeted therapies: oncogenes/tumour suppressors, tumour microenvironment, cell proliferation, cell cycle.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description:
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to timetabled lectures

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description:
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to timetabled tutorials

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Specifically, assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, through the evaluative elements we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Assessment 1 will be a structured, evaluative long piece of writing.

Assessment 2 will be a Structured, evaluative long piece of writing.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Educational Aims
To introduce current techniques and models used to study molecular and cellular physiology;

To review the latest research developments in molecular and cellular physiology and in human diseases, including cancer, obesity, and cystic fibrosis;

To develop in students deep understanding of cellular regulatory physiology mechanisms in order to enhance their ability to discuss the relevant research literature. 
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will build upon Level 5 systems physiology and introduce the techniques and concepts of molecular and cellular physiology. The students will understand the nature of leading research initiatives as they are applied in investigations into physiological processes and human disease. The module will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials, and will be assessed by continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus explores fundamental principles of cellular and molecular physiology, key techniques, and their application in research into human disease.

Topic 1

The central dogma of molecular biology: multi-level regulation of gene/protein expression by transcription factors, chromatin, non-coding RNAs and protein turnover;

Methods to engineer and measure gene expression in cells, tissues and organisms.


Topic 2

Protein biology: structure, function and systems analysis;

Protein folding: mechanisms, prediction and disorders;

Exploring the proteome using quantitative mass spectrometry and interaction mapping, applications in cell biology and human disease.


Topic 3

Imaging physiological processes: from cells to organisms;

Visualising and measuring protein distribution, interactions and dynamics in live cells;

High resolution in vivo imaging in physiology research.


Topic 4

Model organisms in physiology research: from yeast to mice;

The pros and cons of yeast, flies, worms and mice;

Using model organisms to study protein function and interaction networks, stem cells, neurobiology and physiological processes.


Topic 5

Research into human diseases;

Cystic fibrosis: abnormal airway smooth muscle function and the search for improved therapies;

Cancer biology and targeted therapies: oncogenes/tumour suppressors, tumour microenvironment, cell proliferation, cell cycle.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description:
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to timetabled lectures

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description:
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to timetabled tutorials

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Specifically, assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, through the evaluative elements we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Assessment 1 will be a structured, evaluative long piece of writing.

Assessment 2 will be a Structured, evaluative long piece of writing.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Rationale
We are unexpectedly losing the expertise to teach the two obesity lectures on LIFE309 from 2016/17 onwards. The topic requires specialist research insight that we cannot easily replace, and it has been agreed that the most pragmatic solution is to lose these two lectures. This is less than 10% change in the module content, and will have no impact on the learning and teaching, or assessment, strategies.
